fact: Strawberries aren’t actually berries — but bananas are! Botanically, a berry must come from a single flower with one ovary. That makes bananas, kiwis, and even watermelons berries. Strawberries, however, aren’t berries at all — they’re aggregate fruits, meaning each “seed” on the outside is technically its own fruit.

Apples float because they are 25% air. Apples contain enough internal air pockets to make them buoyant. That’s why apple-bobbing works! This also contributes to their crisp, airy texture when you bite into them.

Pineapples take nearly three years to grow. A single pineapple plant produces only one pineapple at a time. After harvesting, it can sprout a new fruit, but the whole process is very slow — which is why pineapples used to be symbols of luxury and wealth.

Oranges are not always orange. In tropical climates, oranges often stay green even when fully ripe because warm temperatures keep the chlorophyll intact. The only reason most oranges look orange is due to cold weather or degreening during commercial processing.

A whole bunch of grapes can explode in the microwave. Grapes trap energy and moisture in a way that can create plasma (superheated gas) when microwaved. This is a fun physics phenomenon — but do not try it at home unless you like cleaning your microwave!
